A cylinder of ice nearly a mile and a half long, painstakingly drawn from the Antarctic icecap by a Soviet and French scientific expedition, has documented 160,000 years of the earth's climate, revealing a surprisingly precise connection between changes in temperature and in the amount of carbon dioxide in the air.

''Fortunately, nature has been taking continuous samples of the atmosphere at the surface of the ice sheets throughout the ages,'' the scientists report in the journal Nature. The Soviet-French data reach back past the ice age that ended 10,000 years ago to the ice age before.

As carbon dioxide concentration falls, so does temperature. As carbon dioxide concentration rises - and it is rising with unprecedented speed now, because of human activity -temperature rises, too. In what is known as the greenhouse effect, atmospheric carbon dioxide traps heat that would otherwise be radiated out to space.

Although the researchers stop short of claiming to have demonstrated a cause-and-effect relationship, they have provided the strongest evidence to date of a link between climate and carbon dioxide. They suggest that carbon dioxide, produced and consumed by biological processes on land and in the oceans, is part of a complex feedback loop, sharply amplifying small changes in the amount of sunlight that reaches earth.
